about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
Traube et al (2014) first developed and tested the CAPD in a single-institution study of 111 children admitted to a tertiary center’s PICU. The scale showed good sensitivity (94% overall) across a wide range of pediatric age groups, including infants. They also did not use developmental delay as a screening factor; while the false positive rate was higher in delayed children, the scale was still viewed as helpful in assessing for the presence of delirium.

The scale showed good interrater reliability and external validity when compared to diagnoses of delirium made by child psychiatrists using DSM-IV criteria. The specificity of the score was relatively high for a screening tool (79%), but suggests that the CAPD is less useful as a diagnostic tool.
about.formula_en:
Addition of the selected points, based on interactions with the patient over the course of one nursing shift. Note that the "best" scores (i.e., associated with absence of delirium) are listed first, e.g. Makes eye contact - always (0 points), Inconsolable - never (0 points).

about.more_info_en:
Interpretation:

CAPD Score

Delirium

Recommendation

≥9

Present

Investigate and treat underlying medical condition(s) causing delirium, consider interventions with parents and child life services, and/or consult to psychiatry or palliative care as appropriate, consider medications like melatonin or QUEtiapine (SEROquel) in select cases

<9

Absent

Continue usual care and monitoring

Original/Primary Reference.text: Traube C, Silver G, Kearney J, et al. Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium: a valid, rapid, observational tool for screening delirium in the PICU*. Crit Care Med. 2014;42(3):656-63.

Other References.text: Daoud A, Duff JP, Joffe AR. Diagnostic accuracy of delirium diagnosis in pediatric intensive care: a systematic review. Crit Care. 2014;18(5):489.

Validation.text: Silver G, Kearney J, Traube C, Hertzig M. Delirium screening anchored in child development: The Cornell Assessment for Pediatric Delirium. Palliat Support Care. 2015;13(4):1005-11.

creator.name: Dr. Chani Traube
creator.qa_en:
Why did you develop the Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium (CAPD)? Was there a particular clinical experience or patient encounter that inspired you to create this tool for clinicians?

In my role as a pediatric intensivist, I noted that many of my patients were not acting appropriately for age—some were extremely agitated and others inappropriately docile. From reading the literature, I knew that delirium was a frequent and severe complication of critical illness in adults. However, this was not well described within pediatrics, mostly due to the absence of a feasible bedside screening tool that could be used in children of all ages. In collaboration with Dr. Gabrielle Silver, an expert child psychiatrist, we developed the Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium (CAPD) to fill that void.

What pearls, pitfalls and/or tips do you have for users of the Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium (CAPD)? Do you know of cases when it has been applied, interpreted, or used inappropriately?

Score the CAPD based on your observation of the child over several hours, not as a single-point-in-time screen.

How do I score the CAPD in children with developmental delay?

SCORE IT AS YOU SEE IT! No need to interpret or adjust for baseline (e.g. if the child never makes eye contact, score as “never”). We do not automatically assume that a CAPD score >9 means delirium in a child with developmental delay, but the numerical score is important and something we trend.

How do I score the CAPD in very young children?

A developmental anchor points chart is available for kids under 2 years of age, to use as a reference if you need it, when scoring the individual items (see Evidence section).

Who needs to be screened for delirium?

EVERY PATIENT, EVERY SHIFT, especially on the day of admission, and even on the day of discharge. The only exclusions are children who are unarousable to verbal stimulation as they cannot be assessed.

What recommendations do you have for doctors once they have applied the Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium (CAPD)? Are there any adjustments or updates you would make to the score based on new data or practice changes?

Some keys to success:

1. Implement delirium screening as standard of care in your unit. Every patient, every shift.

2. Get your colleagues educated and onboard. The nurses will not comply with screening if they present delirium scores on rounds and the doctors don’t know what to do with the information.

3. Add the CAPD tool to your electronic medical record as part of the flowsheet. This will make it much easier for the nurses to score and will allow for monitoring of compliance.

4. Monitor compliance intensively for the first few months.

5. EARLY SUCCESS: a few key patients will make this all work. Your team will recognize and address delirium, and the child will get better. Then they will become believers!

How do you use the Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium (CAPD) in your own clinical practice? Can you give an example of a scenario in which you use it?

Every patient, every shift. Our nurses score the CAPD on every child at approximately 6 pm (end of day shift) and approximately 6 am (end of night shift).

Any other research in the pipeline that you’re particularly excited about?

So much work to be done! We are particularly excited about addressing the modifiable factors for delirium. For example: prescribing practices (including benzodiazepines and anticholinergics) and sleep disruption. We are also very interested in the long-term effects of delirium on children's cognition and psychological health.

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Pediatric delirium often presents differently than that of adults. Children may be more likely to have a catatonia-like presentation, with general listlessness and paucity of speech.

  • Children with developmental delay are at higher risk of developing delirium than non-delayed children, and therefore should be monitored more closely for delirium symptoms.
how_to_use.use_case_en:
• In critically ill pediatric patients aged 0-21 years.

  • May be used in both developmentally normal and delayed patients.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• As in adults, hospitalized children, particularly those in the PICU, are at high risk of developing delirium.

  • In turn, delirium in children is associated with complications such as increased length of stay, post-traumatic stress symptoms, and possible long-term neurodevelopmental issues.

next_steps.advice_en: While all children in the PICU should receive behavioral interventions to prevent potential delirium, making the diagnosis of delirium is often difficult in children. This score can assist the clinician in screening for delirium.
next_steps.critical_actions_en:
• Monitor especially closely for delirium in developmentally delayed children, who are at higher risk than non-delayed children.

  • A positive CAPD screen for delirium should prompt additional intervention and investigation. Consultation with child life specialists or child psychiatry may be beneficial.
next_steps.management_en:
• Reorientation with familiar toys, games, and routines is helpful in managing delirium.

  • Maintenance of normal day/night cycle-based lighting in ICU rooms can be difficult but helpful in the prevention and management of delirium for both children and adults.

  • Pediatric delirium that threatens the safety of the patient, family, or staff, or delirium refractory to behavioral and environmental interventions, may require pharmacologic treatment.

  • Avoidance of early morning blood draws and other testing, which can disrupt normal sleep patterns, can help reduce the risk or severity of delirium.

input_schema.name: age
input_schema.tips_en: Select closest

input_schema.subheading: Assess patient based on interactions over one nursing shift:

input_schema.name: eye1
input_schema.tips_en: Fixates on face

input_schema.name: purpose1
input_schema.tips_en: Moves head to side, dominated by primitive reflexes

input_schema.name: aware1
input_schema.tips_en: Calm awake time

input_schema.name: communication1
input_schema.tips_en: Cries when hungry or uncomfortable

input_schema.name: restless1
input_schema.tips_en: No sustained awake alert state

input_schema.name: incon1
input_schema.tips_en: Not soothed by parental rocking, singing, feeding, comforting actions

input_schema.name: under1
input_schema.tips_en: Little if any flexed and then relaxed state with primitive reflexes   (child should be sleeping comfortably most of the time)

input_schema.label_en: Takes long time to respond to interactions
input_schema.name: time1
input_schema.tips_en: Not making sounds or reflexes active as expected (grasp, suck, moro)

input_schema.name: eye2
input_schema.tips_en: Holds gaze briefly, follows 90°

input_schema.name: purpose2
input_schema.tips_en: Reaches (with some discoordination)

input_schema.name: aware2
input_schema.tips_en: Awake alert time, turns to primary caretaker’s voice, may turn to smell of primary caretaker

input_schema.name: communication2
input_schema.tips_en: Cries when hungry or uncomfortable

input_schema.name: restless2
input_schema.tips_en: No sustained calm state

input_schema.name: incon2
input_schema.tips_en: Not soothed by parental rocking, singing, feeding, comforting actions

input_schema.name: under2
input_schema.tips_en: Little if any reaching, kicking, grasping (still may be somewhat discoordinated)

input_schema.label_en: Takes long time to respond to interactions
input_schema.name: time2
input_schema.tips_en: Not making sounds or reflexes active as expected (grasp, suck, moro)

input_schema.name: eye3
input_schema.tips_en: Holds gaze

input_schema.name: purpose3
input_schema.tips_en: Reaches

input_schema.name: aware3
input_schema.tips_en: Increasing awake alert time, turns to primary caretaker’s voice, may turn to smell of primary caretaker

input_schema.name: communication3
input_schema.tips_en: Cries when hungry or uncomfortable

input_schema.name: restless3
input_schema.tips_en: No sustained calm state

input_schema.name: incon3
input_schema.tips_en: Not soothed by parental rocking, singing, feeding, comforting actions

input_schema.name: under3
input_schema.tips_en: Little if any reaching, kicking, grasping (may begin to be more coordinated)

input_schema.label_en: Takes long time to respond to interactions
input_schema.name: time3
input_schema.tips_en: Not kicking or crying with noxious stimuli

input_schema.name: eye4
input_schema.tips_en: Follows moving object/caregiver past midline, regards examiner’s hand holding object, focused attention

input_schema.name: purpose4
input_schema.tips_en: Symmetric movements, will passively grasp handed object

input_schema.name: aware4
input_schema.tips_en: Facial brightening or smile in response to nodding head, frown to bell, coos

input_schema.name: communication4
input_schema.tips_en: Cries when hungry or uncomfortable

input_schema.name: restless4
input_schema.tips_en: No sustained calm state

input_schema.name: incon4
input_schema.tips_en: Not soothed by parental rocking, singing, feeding, comforting actions

input_schema.name: under4
input_schema.tips_en: Little if any purposive grasping, control of head and arm movements, such as pushing things that are noxious away

input_schema.label_en: Takes long time to respond to interactions
input_schema.name: time4
input_schema.tips_en: Not cooing, smiling, or focusing gaze in response to interactions

input_schema.name: eye5
input_schema.tips_en: Holds gaze, prefers primary parent, looks at speaker

input_schema.name: purpose5
input_schema.tips_en: Reaches with coordinated smooth movement

input_schema.name: aware5
input_schema.tips_en: Strongly prefers mother, then other familiars, differentiates between novel and familiar objects

input_schema.name: communication5
input_schema.tips_en: Vocalizes/indicates about needs, e.g. hunger, discomfort, curiosity in objects, or surroundings

input_schema.name: restless5
input_schema.tips_en: No sustained calm state

input_schema.name: incon5
input_schema.tips_en: Not soothed by usual methods, e.g. singing, holding, talking

input_schema.name: under5
input_schema.tips_en: Little if any reaching, grasping, moving around in bed, pushing things away

input_schema.label_en: Takes long time to respond to interactions
input_schema.name: time5
input_schema.tips_en: Not babbling or smiling/laughing in social interactions (or even actively rejecting an interaction)

input_schema.name: eye6
input_schema.tips_en: Holds gaze, prefers primary parent, looks at speaker

input_schema.name: purpose6
input_schema.tips_en: Reaches and manipulates objects, tries to change position, if mobile, may try to get up

input_schema.name: aware6
input_schema.tips_en: Prefers primary parent, then other familiars, upset when separated from preferred caretakers, comforted by familiar objects especially favorite blanket or stuffed animal

input_schema.name: communication6
input_schema.tips_en: Uses single words, or signs

input_schema.name: restless6
input_schema.tips_en: No sustained calm state

input_schema.name: incon6
input_schema.tips_en: Not soothed by usual methods, e.g. singing, holding, talking, reading

input_schema.name: under6
input_schema.tips_en: Little if any play, efforts to sit up, pull up, and if mobile, crawl or walk around

input_schema.label_en: Takes long time to respond to interactions
input_schema.name: time6
input_schema.tips_en: Not following simple directions, if verbal, not engaging in simple dialogue with words or jargon

input_schema.name: eye7
input_schema.tips_en: Holds gaze, prefers primary parent, looks at speaker

input_schema.name: purpose7
input_schema.tips_en: Reaches and manipulates objects, tries to change position, if mobile, may try to get up and walk

input_schema.name: aware7
input_schema.tips_en: Prefers primary parent, then other familiars, upset when separated from preferred care takers, comforted by familiar objects especially favorite blanket or stuffed animal

input_schema.name: communication7
input_schema.tips_en: Uses 3-4 word sentences, or signs, may indicate toilet needs, calls self or me

input_schema.name: restless7
input_schema.tips_en: No sustained calm state

input_schema.name: incon7
input_schema.tips_en: Not soothed by usual methods, e.g. singing, holding, talking, reading (may tantrum, but can organize)

input_schema.name: under7
input_schema.tips_en: Little if any more elaborate play, efforts to sit up and move around, and if able to stand, walk or jump

input_schema.label_en: Takes long time to respond to interactions
input_schema.name: time7
input_schema.tips_en: Not following  1-2 step simple commands, if verbal, not engaging in more complex dialogue

calc.instructions_en: Do not use in patients with Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) ≤-4 (deep sedation: no response to voice, but movement or eye opening to physical stimulation, or unarousable: no response to voice or physical stimulation). Includes developmental anchor points for children at 8 weeks and 1 year to improve screening accuracy in very young patients.

seo.keywords_en: Peds, pediatric delirium, delirium screen, pediatric delirium screen, capd, Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium
seo.meta_description_en: The Cornell Assessment of Pediatric Delirium (CAPD) screens for pediatric delirium.

contributors.description: Derek Tam, MD, MPH, is a pediatric resident at Maimonides Children's Hospital in Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Tam completed an undergraduate degree in cognitive science at Northwestern University in Chicago, IL, and received his MD and MPH from the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine. He will serve as chief resident for the pediatric residency program at Maimonides for the academic year 2019-2020 and plans to pursue a fellowship in pediatric emergency medicine. His academic interests include emergency medicine, pediatric resuscitation, antibiotic stewardship, and epidemiology.
contributors.name: Derek Tam, MD, MPH

creators.about_en: Chani Traube, MD, is an assistant professor of pediatrics in the department of critical care medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College. She is also a pediatrician at New York-Presbyterian Hospital. Dr. Traube’s primary research is focused on pediatric respiratory failure, shock, and delirium.
creators.name: Dr. Chani Traube

creators.about_en: Gabrielle Silver, MD, is a practicing child and adolescent psychiatrist at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She is also a clinical associate professor of psychiatry at the Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Silver’s primary research is focused on screening critically ill children for delirium.
creators.name: Dr. Gabrielle Silver

cme_faq.answer: MDCalc’s Continuing Medical Education (CME) service allows users to easily earn AMA PRA Category 1 CreditsTM through regular use of MDCalc. Simply put, on top of getting the best medical calculators in the world, your usage will help you achieve your annual CME requirements, including specialty CME, without any extra effort.
cme_faq.question: What is MDCalc CME?

cme_faq.answer: Yes, in support of improving patient care, this activity has been planned and implemented by the Postgraduate Institute for Medicine and MDCalc Ltd. Inc. Postgraduate Institute for Medicine is jointly accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME), the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy Education (ACPE), and the American Nurses Credentialing Center (ANCC), to provide continuing education for the healthcare team.
cme_faq.question: Is MDCalc CME accredited?

cme_faq.answer: Only United States attending physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and physician assistants are eligible for our CME service.
cme_faq.question: Who can enroll and how?

cme_faq.answer: We have over 275 CME-eligible calculators across various specialties. You can read the clinical content supporting any CME calculators to start earning. Once you have viewed all the supporting content for a calculator, you will have officially earned the credit amount (0.5 credits) and will be able to redeem a certificate. For now, only calc content in CME-eligible calcs is eligible for CME credits, however, we’ll be expanding our CME service to include more of our content in the future.
cme_faq.question: What activities can I do to earn CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: Simply use our search bar or visit our homepage to easily find CME-eligible calcs. You must be enrolled in our CME service to see which calcs are CME-eligible.
cme_faq.question: Where can I find calcs with which I can earn credits?

cme_faq.answer: Once you’ve enrolled in our CME service, you will have a personal CME Dashboard where you can view all of your earned credits. You can navigate to the dashboard by clicking the CME button in the header at the top of any page.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see which credits I’ve earned?

cme_faq.answer: Go to your CME Dashboard and select the credits you’d like to redeem, fill out a few dropdown answers about how you used the calc, and then proceed to checkout.
cme_faq.question: How do I redeem CME credits?

cme_faq.answer: No. Earning credits as you use calcs is free, but either you (or your employer) will need to purchase an annual subscription to redeem your CME certificates.
cme_faq.question: Are CME credits free?

cme_faq.answer: Just like with earned credits, you can view your CME certificates on your CME Dashboard in the “CME Certificates” tab. Certificates include a list of all of the calcs for which CME was earned along with a tally of the specialty CME.
cme_faq.question: Where can I see my CME certificates?

cme_faq.answer: One year from the date of purchase.
cme_faq.question: How long do credits in an annual subscription last?

cme_faq.answer: General; Addiction and Controlled Substances; Cardiac Care; Domestic and Intimate Partner Violence; Geriatrics; HIV and Infectious Disease; Hospice, End-of-Life, Terminal Illness, and Palliative Care; Mental and Behavioral Health; Pain Management; Pediatrics; Stroke; and Trauma.
cme_faq.question: What specialty CME credits are included in the plan?

cme_faq.answer:
Your gift card will be sent via email within 1-2 business days of making your purchase. You will be able to select from the following options - Visa, Amazon.com, Apple. Be sure to claim your gift card offer within 90 days of receiving the email.

Your CME purchase may have implications for tax reporting purposes. The cost of your CME product may or may not be tax-deductible when used for professional purposes. Any reimbursed amount for incentives must be declared as personal income for tax purposes. Please consult your tax advisor. MDCalc does not provide tax advice.
cme_faq.question: I ordered a CME package with a gift card. How does it work?

cme_faq.answer: Per the new guidelines from ACCME, the receipt will separate the cost you paid into the cost of the gift card and the cost of the CME learning activity.
cme_faq.question: What will show on my receipt for CME when it includes a gift card?

cme_faq.answer: You can get a refund (minus any promotional gift amount) within 30-days if the ease of earning and redeeming does not meet your expectations and if you have redeemed no more than 4 credits. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request a refund.
cme_faq.question: How do I get a refund if I'm not satisfied?

cme_faq.answer: You can upgrade your subscription throughout your billing cycle and pay the difference for a higher plan. You may request to downgrade your plan to a lower level to coincide with your next renewal. Please email team@mdcalc.com to request changes.
cme_faq.question: How do I later upgrade to a different plan if I need more credits?

cme_faq.answer: Gift card plans are available for 1 year and do not auto-renew. Standard, non gift-card subscriptions are auto-renewed annually. You can disable the automatic renewal of your subscription at any time by emailing team@mdcalc.com.
cme_faq.question: Do CME plans auto-renew?

cme_faq.answer: If you’re part of a team or practice that wants to sign up five or more physicians, please email us at team@mdcalc.com for more information.
cme_faq.question: How do I get information on a discounted bulk subscription program for my institution, team, or practice?

cme_faq.answer: On July 28, 2022, ACCME updated the guidelines regarding the use of high-value incentives. These guidelines allow for the use of gift card rewards in a regulated manner. Visit the ACCME website to read their guidelines.
cme_faq.question: Did the ACCME decide to regulate gift cards?
